definition: An expression containing a root symbol, such as a square root or cube root.
The process of eliminating a radical from the denominator of a fraction.
A root symbol used to denote the root of a number.
An equation of the form ax^2 + bx + c = 0 where a, b, and c are constants.
A number or algebraic expression that divides another number or expression evenly.
A branch of mathematics dealing with symbols and the rules for manipulating those symbols.
A set of values that show an exact position in a space or plane.
A relation between a set of inputs and a set of permissible outputs where each input is related to exactly one output.
A relationship between two numbers indicating how many times the first number contains the second.
An equation that states that two ratios are equal.
The sum of a set of values divided by the number of values.
The middle value in a list of numbers sorted in ascending or descending order.
The value that appears most frequently in a data set.
A measure of how much values in a data set differ from the mean.
A measure of the amount of variation or dispersion in a set of values.
A fraction or ratio expressed as a part of 100.
An ordered list of numbers following a specific pattern.
The sum of the terms of a sequence.
The power to which a number or expression is raised.
The exponent or power to which a base number must be raised to obtain a given number.
The branch of mathematics dealing with the relationships between the angles and sides of triangles.
In trigonometry, the ratio of the length of the opposite side to the hypotenuse in a right-angled triangle.
In trigonometry, the ratio of the length of the adjacent side to the hypotenuse in a right-angled triangle.
In trigonometry, the ratio of the length of the opposite side to the adjacent side in a right-angled triangle.
The branch of mathematics involving points, lines, planes, and figures, and their properties, measurement, and mutual relations.
The space between two intersecting lines or surfaces measured in degrees.
Lines or planes that are equidistant from each other at all points and never meet.
Lines or surfaces that intersect at a right angle (90 degrees).
A plane figure with at least three straight sides and angles, typically five or more.
A round plane figure whose boundary (the circumference) consists of points equidistant from the center.
The distance from the center of a circle to any point on its circumference.
A straight line passing from side to side through the center of a circle or sphere.
The distance around the edge of a circle.
The extent or measurement of a surface, typically in square units.
The amount of space that a substance or object occupies.
A rectangular array of numbers or expressions arranged in rows and columns.
A value calculated from the elements of a square matrix that provides information about the matrix.
A quantity having direction as well as magnitude.
A quantity that only has magnitude and no direction.
A statement that has been proven to be true based on axioms and previously established theorems.
A logical argument demonstrating the truth of a theorem or statement.
The quality of being identical in form and size; having the same shape and size.
The property of having the same shape but not necessarily the same size.
The process of finding the derivative of a function.
The process of finding the integral of a function, representing the area under the curve.
A value that a function or sequence approaches as the input or index approaches some value.
The measure of the likelihood of an event occurring.
A function that shows the possible values of a variable and how often they occur.
A probability distribution that is symmetric about the mean, showing that data near the mean are more frequent in occurrence.
An algebraic expression with two terms separated by a plus or minus sign.
A direction or angle relative to a reference direction, typically used in navigation and geometry.
Equal distance from two or more points.
An operation that moves or changes a shape in some way to produce a new shape.
Describing a relationship or function that forms a straight line when graphed.
Describing a relationship or function that does not form a straight line when graphed.
A numerical or constant quantity placed before and multiplying the variable in an algebraic expression.
A fixed value that does not change.
The multiplicative inverse of a number, such that the product of a number and its reciprocal is 1.
A number that can be expressed in the form a + bi where a and b are real numbers and i is the imaginary unit.
The square root of -1, used to define complex numbers.
A formula used to solve quadratic equations: x = (-b ± √(b² - 4ac)) / 2a.
A coordinate system where each point on a plane is determined by a distance from a reference point and an angle from a reference direction.
Equations where the coordinates of the points are expressed as functions of a parameter.
An equation that involves derivatives of a function or functions.
A technique used to integrate products of functions by transforming them into simpler integrals.
A method for breaking down rational functions into simpler fractions that are easier to integrate.
A scalar that indicates how much a corresponding eigenvector is stretched or compressed during a linear transformation.
A non-zero vector that changes by only a scalar factor when a linear transformation is applied.
A binary operation that produces a matrix from two matrices by performing a specific summation of products.
A scalar value that can be computed from the elements of a square matrix and provides information about the matrix.
Equations involving trigonometric functions that are true for all values of the variables involved.
A formula for expressing the powers of a binomial as a sum of terms involving coefficients, powers of the variables, and factorials.
A method used to find the local maxima and minima of a function subject to equality constraints.
A way to represent a function as the sum of simple sine waves.
A representation of a function as an infinite sum of terms calculated from the values of its derivatives at a single point.
The exponent or power to which a base number must be raised to obtain a given number.
An equation that recursively defines a sequence of values using previous terms.
A two-dimensional plane where complex numbers are represented as points or vectors.
A type of conic section that is the locus of points where the difference of the distances to two fixed points is constant.
A type of conic section that is the locus of points where the sum of the distances to two fixed points is constant.
The curves obtained by intersecting a cone with a plane, which include ellipses, hyperbolas, and parabolas.
A line that a graph approaches but never touches or crosses.
An operation that moves or changes a shape in some way to produce a new shape.
A mapping between two vector spaces that preserves the operations of vector addition and scalar multiplication.
Functions or equations where the relationship between variables is not linear.
A numerical or constant quantity placed before a variable in an algebraic expression.
A fixed value that does not change.
The multiplicative inverse of a number or expression, such that the product of a number and its reciprocal is 1.
An algebraic expression consisting of two terms separated by a plus or minus sign.
The direction or position of one point relative to another, usually expressed in degrees.
At equal distances from two or more points.
The basic structural and functional unit of all living organisms.
An organelle in eukaryotic cells that contains the genetic material (DNA).
The jelly-like substance within a cell, excluding the nucleus, where cellular processes occur.
Organelles known as the powerhouses of the cell, responsible for producing energy through respiration.
An organelle in plant cells that contains chlorophyll and is responsible for photosynthesis.
The process by which green plants and some other organisms use sunlight to synthesize foods with the help of chlorophyll.
Proteins that act as biological catalysts, speeding up chemical reactions in cells.
A molecule that carries genetic instructions used in growth, development, functioning, and reproduction.
A segment of DNA that codes for a specific trait or function.
Thread-like structures made of DNA molecules that contain the genes.
A change in the DNA sequence that can lead to changes in the organism's traits.
The genetic constitution of an organism, often referring to a specific gene or set of genes.
The observable physical or biochemical characteristics of an organism, as determined by both genetic makeup and environmental influences.
An allele that expresses its trait even when only one copy is present.
An allele that only expresses its trait when two copies are present.
Different forms of a gene that can exist at a specific locus.
A biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment.
A large naturally occurring community of flora and fauna occupying a major habitat.
A series of organisms each dependent on the next as a source of food.
The levels of nourishment in a food chain.
The process by which living organisms regulate their internal environment to maintain stable conditions.
The regulation of the osmotic pressure of bodily fluids to maintain homeostasis.
The process by which molecules spread from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration.
The diffusion of water through a selectively permeable membrane.
The movement of molecules across a cell membrane from a region of lower concentration to a region of higher concentration, using energy.
The process of converting glucose and oxygen into energy, carbon dioxide, and water.
The process by which plants use sunlight to synthesize foods with chlorophyll.
The biological process by which new individual organisms are produced.
A mode of reproduction where offspring arise from a single organism and inherit the genes of that parent only.
A mode of reproduction involving the combination of genetic material from two parents.
The process by which organisms grow and mature over time.
The process by which a species becomes better suited to its environment.
The diversity in gene frequencies within a population.
The process by which organisms better adapted to their environment tend to survive and produce more offspring.
A change in the DNA sequence of an organism.
The use of living organisms or their products to modify human health and the environment.
The direct manipulation of an organism's genes using biotechnology.
The process of creating a genetically identical copy of an organism.
The total mass of living matter within a given unit of environmental area.
The process by which organic substances are broken down into simpler organic matter.
The circulation of nutrients between living organisms and the environment.
A close and often long-term interaction between two different biological species.
A type of symbiosis where one organism benefits at the expense of another.
A type of symbiosis where both organisms benefit from the interaction.
A type of symbiosis where one organism benefits while the other is neither helped nor harmed.
The regulation of an organism's internal environment to maintain stable conditions.
The branch of biology concerned with the structure of organisms and their parts.
The branch of biology that deals with the normal functions of living organisms and their parts.
An individual living thing, such as a plant, animal, or bacterium.
A group of tissues in a living organism that have a specific function.
A group of cells with similar structures and functions.
An individual living thing, such as a plant, animal, or bacterium.
A protein molecule that receives and responds to signals or stimuli from the environment.
Chemical substances produced by glands that regulate various functions in the body.
A system of cells, tissues, and organs that work together to defend the body against harmful pathogens.
A protein produced by the immune system that recognizes and neutralizes pathogens.
A substance that induces an immune response, especially the production of antibodies.
The smallest unit of an element that retains the properties of that element, consisting of a nucleus and surrounding electrons.
A substance that consists of only one type of atom and cannot be broken down into simpler substances.
A substance formed when two or more elements are chemically bonded together.
A combination of two or more substances where each retains its chemical properties and can be separated by physical means.
A group of atoms bonded together, representing the smallest fundamental unit of a chemical compound.
A type of chemical bond formed between two ions with opposite charges.
A type of chemical bond where two atoms share one or more pairs of electrons.
A type of chemical bond found in metals, where electrons are shared in a 'sea' of delocalized electrons.
A process in which substances (reactants) are transformed into different substances (products).
A representation of a chemical reaction using symbols and formulas.
The calculation of reactants and products in chemical reactions based on the conservation of mass.
A substance that donates protons (H+ ions) and has a pH less than 7.
A substance that accepts protons (H+ ions) and has a pH greater than 7.
A compound formed from the reaction of an acid and a base, typically consisting of a cation from the base and an anion from the acid.
A scale used to measure the acidity or basicity of a solution, ranging from 0 to 14.
The amount of a substance in a given volume of solution.
A measure of concentration, specifically the number of moles of solute per liter of solution.
The process of reducing the concentration of a solute in a solution, usually by adding more solvent.
A chemical process in which a substance loses electrons.
A chemical process in which a substance gains electrons.
A type of reaction involving the transfer of electrons between two species, combining oxidation and reduction processes.
A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without being consumed in the process.
The minimum amount of energy required to start a chemical reaction.
The principle stating that mass cannot be created or destroyed in a chemical reaction.
The total heat content of a system, used to measure the heat absorbed or released during a chemical reaction.
A measure of the disorder or randomness in a system.
The minimum energy required for a chemical reaction to occur.
The state in which the forward and reverse reactions occur at equal rates, so the concentrations of reactants and products remain constant.
The ability of a substance to dissolve in a solvent, forming a solution.
The process by which a solid changes directly into a gas without passing through the liquid phase.
The process by which a gas changes directly into a solid without passing through the liquid phase.
A process that uses electrical energy to drive a non-spontaneous chemical reaction.
The branch of physics dealing with the behavior of particles at atomic and subatomic levels.
The number of protons in the nucleus of an atom, which determines the element's identity.
The total number of protons and neutrons in an atom's nucleus.
Variants of a particular chemical element that have the same number of protons but a different number of neutrons.
A tabular arrangement of the chemical elements organized by increasing atomic number and recurring chemical properties.
A horizontal row in the periodic table of elements.
A vertical column in the periodic table, which contains elements with similar chemical properties.
Electrons in the outermost shell of an atom that are involved in chemical bonding.
Elements in Group 18 of the periodic table, known for their lack of reactivity due to having a full valence shell.
Elements found in the d-block of the periodic table, known for their ability to form various oxidation states.
A substance that increases the rate of a chemical reaction without being consumed in the process.
The process of combining simpler substances to form a more complex product.
The breakdown of a compound into simpler substances.
A type of chemical reaction where one element replaces another in a compound.
A chemical reaction where the ions of two compounds exchange places in an aqueous solution to form two new compounds.
A chemical reaction where a substance combines with oxygen, releasing energy in the form of heat and light.
A measure of the degree of oxidation of an atom in a substance.
A formula that shows the simplest whole-number ratio of elements in a compound.
A formula that shows the actual number of atoms of each element in a molecule.
The percentage by mass of each element in a compound.
The system of naming chemical compounds and elements.
Numbers used in a chemical equation to balance the quantities of reactants and products.
A hypothetical gas that perfectly follows the gas laws, with molecules that do not interact with each other.
Gases that do not behave exactly as ideal gases due to interactions between molecules and finite molecular volume.
The laws that describe the behavior of gases, including Boyle's law, Charles's law, and Avogadro's law.
The principle that the pressure of a given mass of gas is inversely proportional to its volume at constant temperature.
The principle that the volume of a gas is directly proportional to its temperature at constant pressure.
The principle that equal volumes of gases, at the same temperature and pressure, contain an equal number of molecules.
The rate at which an object changes its position, including direction.
The rate of change of velocity of an object.
An interaction that changes the motion of an object.
The capacity to do work or the ability to cause change.
The quantity of motion an object has, calculated as mass times velocity.
The process of energy transfer to an object when a force moves it.
The rate at which work is done or energy is transferred.
An interaction that changes the motion of an object.
A region of space surrounding a mass within which another mass experiences a force of gravitational attraction.
The range of all types of electromagnetic radiation.
The bending of light as it passes from one medium to another.
The bending of waves around obstacles and openings.
The phenomenon where two waves superpose to form a resultant wave of greater or lesser amplitude.
A closed loop through which electric current flows.
The flow of electric charge around a circuit.
The difference in electric potential between two points in a circuit.
A measure of how much an object resists the flow of current.
The principle that the current through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the voltage across the two points.
The rate at which energy is transferred or converted.
The internal energy of an object due to the kinetic energy of its atoms and molecules.
The transfer of heat through a material without the movement of the material itself.
The transfer of heat by the movement of fluid (liquid or gas).
The transfer of energy through electromagnetic waves.
Energy released during nuclear fission or fusion.
The process by which unstable atomic nuclei lose energy by emitting radiation.
The positively charged central core of an atom containing protons and neutrons.
A measure of the amount of matter in an object.
The force exerted on a mass due to gravity.
The quantity of motion an object has, calculated as mass times velocity.
The number of waves that pass a point per unit time.
The distance between successive peaks of a wave.
A disturbance that transfers energy through a medium or space.
A wave in which the motion of the medium is perpendicular to the direction of the wave.
A wave in which the motion of the medium is parallel to the direction of the wave.
The bending of light as it passes from one medium to another.
The bending of waves around obstacles and the spreading of waves when they pass through small openings.
The combination of two or more waves that results in a new wave pattern.
A wave of electric and magnetic fields that travels through space.
A small localized object to which can be ascribed physical properties such as volume or mass.
The smallest amount of a physical quantity that can exist independently.
A quantum of electromagnetic radiation, typically regarded as a particle of light.
A field around a charged particle where other charges experience a force.
A field around a magnet where magnetic forces are observed.
The branch of physics concerned with the interaction of electric and magnetic fields.
Electric charge at rest, often caused by friction.
The branch of physics dealing with heat and temperature and their relation to energy and work.
A measure of the disorder or randomness in a system.
The mass per unit volume of a substance.
The force applied perpendicular to the surface of an object per unit area.
The force exerted by a fluid that opposes an object's weight, causing it to float or rise.
A measure of the force causing an object to rotate around an axis.
Motion that repeats itself in a regular cycle, such as a pendulum or a spring.
The concept that every particle or quantum entity exhibits both wave-like and particle-like properties.
A step-by-step procedure or formula for solving a problem or performing a task.
A storage location identified by a memory address and an associated symbolic name (an identifier), which contains some known or unknown quantity of information referred to as a value.
A classification that specifies which type of value a variable can hold and what operations can be performed on it.
A block of code designed to perform a particular task; it can take inputs, process them, and return a result.
A sequence of instructions that is continually repeated until a certain condition is reached.
A programming construct that executes different code depending on whether a condition evaluates to true or false.
A data structure consisting of a collection of elements, each identified by at least one array index or key.
An instance of a class in object-oriented programming that encapsulates data and methods.
A blueprint for creating objects in object-oriented programming, defining a set of properties and methods.
A mechanism in object-oriented programming where a new class derives from an existing class, inheriting its properties and methods.
The ability of different classes to be treated as instances of the same class through a common interface.
The bundling of data with the methods that operate on that data, restricting direct access to some of an object's components.
A process where a function calls itself directly or indirectly to solve a problem.
The repetition of a process or set of instructions in a loop until a certain condition is met.
The process of finding and fixing bugs or errors in a computer program.
The set of rules that defines the combinations of symbols that are considered to be correctly structured programs or expressions in a programming language.
A program that translates code written in a high-level programming language into machine code or intermediate code.
A program that executes instructions written in a programming language by translating them into machine code line-by-line.
An organized collection of structured information or data stored electronically in a computer system.
A domain-specific language used in programming and managing relational databases.
A collection of computers and devices connected together for sharing resources and information.
A set of rules or standards that define how data is transmitted and received over a network.
A unique string of numbers separated by periods that identifies each computer using the Internet Protocol to communicate over a network.
A protocol used for transmitting hypertext via the World Wide Web.
The address of a web page on the Internet.
The delivery of computing services over the internet, including storage, processing, and data management.
The process of converting information or data into a code to prevent unauthorized access.
The process of converting encrypted data back into its original form.
The physical parts of a computer system, including the central processing unit (CPU), memory, and peripherals.
The programs and other operating information used by a computer.
System software that manages computer hardware and software resources and provides common services for computer programs.
The space where interactions between humans and machines occur, allowing users to control and receive feedback from the machine.
Hardware used to provide data and control signals to a computer.
Hardware used to communicate the results of data processing from a computer.
A base-2 numeral system used to represent text or computer processor instructions using only two symbols, typically 0 and 1.
The smallest unit of data in a computer, represented as either 0 or 1.
A group of binary digits or bits (usually 8) operated on as a unit.
A set of rules governing the exchange or transmission of data between devices.
A measure of the amount of resources required for an algorithm to run, such as time or memory.
The physical components of a computer system.
The programs and operating information used by a computer.
The theory explaining the movement of the Earth's lithosphere which is divided into plates.
The shaking of the Earth's surface caused by the sudden release of energy from the Earth's crust.
A rupture in the Earth's crust where magma, ash, and gases can escape to the surface.
The process by which natural forces like wind or water wear away rocks and soil.
The breakdown of rocks into smaller pieces through physical or chemical processes.
The process of settling or being deposited as sediment.
A natural feature of the Earth's surface, such as mountains, valleys, and plateaus.
A large, persistent body of ice that moves slowly over land.
The continuous movement of water on, above, and below the surface of the Earth.
Any form of water, liquid or solid, falling from the atmosphere, such as rain, snow, or hail.
Water from rain, snowmelt, or other sources that flows over the ground and returns to streams and rivers.
The long-term average of weather patterns in a particular area.
The state of the atmosphere at a specific time and place, including temperature, humidity, and precipitation.
A large ecological community of plants and animals adapting to a particular climate.
A biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment.
Development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.
The process by which cities grow or by which societies become more urban.
Relating to or characteristic of the countryside rather than the town.
The number of people living per unit of area, typically per square kilometer or mile.
The movement of people from one place to another, often for economic, social, or environmental reasons.
The large-scale removal of forests, often to make way for agriculture or urban development.
The process by which fertile land becomes desert as a result of drought, deforestation, or inappropriate agriculture.
Energy derived from resources that are naturally replenished, such as solar, wind, or hydro power.
Resources that cannot be replenished once they are used up, such as fossil fuels and minerals.
The study of the effects of geography on international politics and relations.
The science or practice of drawing maps.
The direction or position of one point relative to another, often measured in degrees.
The ratio of a distance on a map to the corresponding distance on the ground.
Long-term changes in temperature and weather patterns, often attributed to human activities.
A natural event that has the potential to cause harm to people, property, or the environment.
The process of evaluating the potential risks that may be involved in a projected activity or undertaking.
A local warming of urban areas compared to their rural surroundings due to human activities and built environments.
Relating to the interaction between social and economic factors.
A crescent-shaped lake formed when a river meander is cut off from the main flow.
A tall, steep rock formation isolated from the mainland, formed by erosion.
A remnant of a sea stack that has eroded down to a lower level.
A natural underground chamber, often formed by the dissolution of soluble rocks.
A rock formation where an opening has been eroded through the rock, creating a bridge-like structure.
An icicle-shaped mineral deposit that hangs from the ceiling of a cave, formed by dripping water.
A mound-shaped mineral deposit that rises from the floor of a cave, formed by dripping water.
A long, narrow deep inlet of the sea between high cliffs or steep slopes, formed by glacial activity.
A landform where a river meets a body of water and deposits sediment, creating a fan-shaped area.
A coastal area where freshwater from rivers meets and mixes with saltwater from the sea.
A winding curve or bend in a river or stream.
A hill of loose sand built by wind or water flow.
Erosion caused by the friction of sediment-laden water, ice, or wind rubbing against rock surfaces.
The process of wearing down or rubbing away of rock surfaces by friction or erosion.
The process where rocks and sediment are worn down by colliding with other particles.
Erosion caused by the force of moving water compressing air in cracks in rocks.
Erosion caused by the chemical action of water dissolving soluble rocks.
The land area where all water flows to a common outlet such as a river or lake.
The boundary dividing two adjacent drainage basins.
A geological formation that can store and transmit water, typically an underground layer of water-bearing rock or sediment.
A social and economic system in medieval Europe where land was exchanged for military service and protection.
A fundamental change in political power or organizational structures, often accompanied by upheaval.
A policy of extending a country's power and influence through colonization, use of military force, or other means.
The practice of acquiring and maintaining colonies or territories, often through conquest and exploitation.
A political system where a single ruler holds absolute power, often justified by divine right.
An intellectual and cultural movement in the 17th and 18th centuries emphasizing reason, individualism, and skepticism of traditional doctrines.
A period of cultural revival and renewed interest in classical art, literature, and learning, spanning roughly the 14th to the 17th centuries.
The process of transforming economies from agrarian to industrial through technological advances and increased production.
A political ideology that emphasizes the interests and culture of a particular nation, often in opposition to foreign influence.
A political and economic system where the means of production and distribution are owned or regulated by the community as a whole.
A political and economic ideology advocating for a classless society and the abolition of private property, with collective ownership of resources.
An economic system characterized by private ownership of the means of production and operation for profit.
A system of government where power is vested in the people, who rule either directly or through elected representatives.
A political system where the state holds total authority and seeks to control all aspects of public and private life.
Basic rights and freedoms that belong to every person, regardless of nationality, ethnicity, or religion.
An extensive group of territories controlled by a single nation, often through colonization and subjugation.
A formal agreement between countries or governments that is legally binding.
Changes made to improve a system, institution, or practice, often to address social, political, or economic issues.
Relating to or advocating for significant and often abrupt change in political or social systems.
The granting of the right to vote to individuals or groups who were previously excluded.
A political system where a single ruler, such as a king or queen, holds supreme authority.
A form of government where power is concentrated in the hands of a single leader or a small group, often without democratic consent.
A conflict between groups within the same country, often involving competing factions for control of the government.
The genocide during World War II in which six million Jews and millions of others were systematically murdered by the Nazis.
A policy or system of segregation or discrimination on grounds of race, notably in South Africa from 1948 to 1994.
The practice of acquiring and maintaining colonies, often by force or coercion, for economic and political gain.
The condition in which individuals are owned by others and forced to work without freedom.
A political ideology that emphasizes the interests, culture, and identity of a particular nation, often in opposition to foreign influence.
A political and economic ideology advocating for a classless society and the abolition of private property, with collective ownership of resources.
A form of government in which the country is considered a 'public matter' and the head of state is elected, not a monarch.
The peace treaty that ended World War I, imposing heavy reparations and territorial losses on Germany.
A severe worldwide economic downturn that took place during the 1930s, affecting many countries.
The state of political and military tension between the United States and the Soviet Union and their respective allies after World War II.
The rights of citizens to political and social freedom and equality.
The practice of managing international relations and negotiating agreements between countries.
A policy of extending a nation's territory or influence through colonization, conquest, or economic and political means.
Compensation demanded by a victor from a defeated nation, often in the form of money or goods.
An intellectual movement emphasizing reason, science, and individualism, prevalent in the 17th and 18th centuries.
The study of designing equipment and devices that fit the human body, its movements, and its cognitive abilities.
An early sample or model of a product used to test and validate design concepts.
The use of computer software to create, modify, analyze, or optimize designs.
The use of computer software and machinery to automate manufacturing processes.
The study of the properties of materials and their applications in engineering and manufacturing.
Designing products and processes with minimal environmental impact and promoting resource efficiency.
The study of beauty and design principles that influence visual appeal and user experience.
Design principles that enhance user comfort and efficiency by considering human anatomy and behavior.
The ability of a product or system to perform its intended functions effectively and efficiently.
The space where interactions between humans and machines occur, including visual and tactile elements.
The stages a product goes through from inception and development to disposal or recycling.
A document outlining the objectives, requirements, and constraints of a design project.
The process of creating a representation of a product or system to test and refine design ideas.
The process of evaluating a prototype to assess its functionality, performance, and user experience.
The process of converting raw materials into finished products through various techniques and processes.
Methods used to connect or assemble materials, such as welding, soldering, or adhesive bonding.
The process of putting together various components or parts to create a finished product.
The process of constructing products from raw materials through cutting, shaping, and assembling.
The study of designing products and environments to optimize human well-being and overall system performance.
A process of creating three-dimensional objects by layering material based on a digital model.
Attributes of materials that define their behavior and suitability for different applications, such as strength, flexibility, and thermal conductivity.
Designing products and systems inspired by nature's models and processes.
The process of determining the cost of producing a product or service, including materials, labor, and overhead.
Design practices aimed at making products easier and more cost-effective to manufacture.
Design practices focused on making products easier to assemble by reducing complexity and the number of parts.
Design strategies that facilitate the easy disassembly of products for repair, recycling, or disposal.
Materials that have a minimal environmental impact throughout their lifecycle, from extraction to disposal.
The overall experience a user has with a product or system, including ease of use, efficiency, and satisfaction.
The process of repeatedly refining a prototype based on testing and feedback to improve its design and functionality.
The benefit gained by using a mechanical device or system to increase force or efficiency in a task.
Properties of materials that describe their behavior in response to temperature changes, such as thermal conductivity and expansion.
The process of evaluating a product to ensure it meets design specifications and performance standards.
A system of maintaining standards in manufactured products by testing samples of the output against specifications.
A figure of speech where a word or phrase is applied to an object or action to which it is not literally applicable, suggesting a resemblance.
A figure of speech that compares two different things using 'like' or 'as' to highlight similarities.
The repetition of the same initial consonant sound in a sequence of words.
A figure of speech in which a non-human subject is given human characteristics.
An exaggerated statement or claim not meant to be taken literally, used for emphasis or effect.
A literary device where the intended meaning is opposite to the literal meaning, often used to create humor or emphasize a point.
A literary device used to give hints or clues about events that will occur later in the narrative.
The use of symbols to represent ideas or qualities beyond their literal sense.
Descriptive language that appeals to the senses and creates a vivid mental picture.
The general character or attitude of a piece of writing, reflecting the writer's feelings or perspective.
The emotional atmosphere created by a piece of writing, affecting the reader's feelings.
The repetition of similar sounds at the end of lines in poetry or songs.
The pattern of stressed and unstressed syllables in a line of poetry or prose, creating a flow or beat.
A 14-line poem with a specific rhyme scheme and meter, traditionally written in iambic pentameter.
A situation in a narrative where the audience knows more about the events or outcomes than the characters do.
An indirect or passing reference to a person, place, event, or literary work outside the text.
The placement of two or more elements side by side to highlight their differences or similarities.
A spoken or written account of connected events; a story.
The main character in a story, drama, or other narrative work.
A character or force in opposition to the protagonist, creating conflict in the narrative.
The sequence of events that make up a story, including the conflict, climax, and resolution.
The time and place where the story takes place.
The central idea or underlying message of a literary work.
The struggle between opposing forces in a narrative, which drives the plot.
The conversation between characters in a literary work.
A speech delivered by a character alone on stage, revealing their inner thoughts.
A long speech by one character in a play or narrative, often revealing their thoughts and feelings.
A figure of speech where contrasting ideas are presented in a parallel structure.
A figure of speech in which contradictory terms appear in conjunction.
A play on words that exploits multiple meanings or similar-sounding words for comedic or rhetorical effect.
The marks used in writing to separate sentences and clarify meaning, such as periods, commas, and exclamation points.
The arrangement of words and phrases to create well-formed sentences in a language.
The choice and use of words and phrases in writing, influencing the tone and clarity of the text.
The level of formality or style used in a piece of writing, varying according to the audience and purpose.
The art of persuasive speaking or writing, using various techniques to influence or convince an audience.
